ol.li: Understand the relationship between the dot product, length, and distance.
Understand the relationship between the dot product and orthogonality.
Vocabulary: dot product, length, distance, unit vector, unit vector in the direction of x.

subsection.title: The Dot Product
subsection.p: The basic construction in this section is the dot product, which measures angles between vectors and computes the length of a vector.

statement.p:
The dot product of two vectors x,y in \R^n is
x\cdot y = \vec{x_1 x_2 \vdots, x_n} \cdot \vec{y_1 y_2 \vdots, y_n} \;=\; x_1y_1 + x_2y_2 + \cdots + x_ny_n.
Thinking of x,y as column vectors, this is the same as x^Ty.

subsection.p:
For example,
\vec{1 2 3}\cdot\vec{4 5 6} = \mat{1 2 3}\vec{4 5 6} = 1\cdot 4 + 2\cdot 5 + 3\cdot 6 = 32.
Notice that the dot product of two vectors is a scalar.
You can do arithmetic with dot products mostly as usual, as long as you remember you can only dot two vectors together, and that the result is a scalar.

note.title: Properties of the Dot Product
note.p:
Let x,y,z be vectors in \R^n and let c be a scalar.
Commutativity: x\cdot y = y \cdot x.
Distributivity with addition: (x + y)\cdot z = x\cdot z+y\cdot z.
Compatibility with scalar multiplication: (cx)\cdot y = c(x\cdot y).

subsection.p:
The dot product of a vector with itself is an important special case:
\vec{x_1 x_2 \vdots, x_n}\cdot\vec{x_1 x_2 \vdots, x_n} = x_1^2 + x_2^2 + \cdots + x_n^2.
Therefore, for any vector x, we have:
x\cdot x \geq 0
x\cdot x = 0 \iff x = 0.
This leads to a good definition of length.

statement.p:
The length of a vector x in \R^n is the number
\|x\| = \sqrt{x\cdot x} = \sqrt{x_1^2 + x_2^2 + \cdots + x_n^2}.

subsection.p: Note that the length of a vector is the length of the arrow; if we think in terms of points, then the length is its distance from the origin.

statement.p: Suppose that \|x\| = 2,\;\|y\|=3, and x\cdot y = -4. What is \|2x + 3y\|?

fact.p: If x is a vector and c is a scalar, then \|cx\|=|c|\cdot\|x\|.

subsection.p:
This says that scaling a vector by c scales its length by |c|. For example,
\left\|\vec{6 8}\right\| = \left\|2\vec{3 4}\right\| = 2\left\|\vec{3 4}\right\| = 10.

Now that we have a good notion of length, we can define the distance between points in \R^n. Recall that the difference between two points x,y is naturally a vector, namely, the vector y-x pointing from x to y.

statement.p: The distance between two points x,y in \R^n is the length of the vector from x to y: \dist(x,y) = \|y-x\|.

subsection.p: Vectors with length 1 are very common in applications, so we give them a name.

statement.p: A unit vector is a vector x with length \|x\| = \sqrt{x\cdot x} =1.

subsection.p: Standard coordinate vectorsare unit vectors Unit vectorstandard coordinate vectors The standard coordinate vectors e_1,e_2,e_3,\ldots are unit vectors: \|e_1\| = \left\|\vec{1 0 0}\right\| = \sqrt{1^2 + 0^2 + 0^2} = 1. For any nonzero vector x, there is a unique unit vector pointing in the same direction. It is obtained by dividing by the length of x.

unit vector in the direction of

statement.p: Let x be a nonzero vector in \R^n. The unit vector in the direction of x is the vector x/\|x\|.

subsection.p:
This is in fact a unit vector (noting that \|x\| is a positive number, so \bigl|1/\|x\|\bigr| = 1/\|x\|):
\left\|\frac{x}{\|x\|}\right\| = \frac 1{\|x\|}\|x\| = 1.

subsection.title: Orthogonal Vectors
subsection.p: In this section, we show how the dot product can be used to define orthogonality, i.e., when two vectors are perpendicular to each other.

statement.p: Two vectors x,y in \R^n are orthogonal or perpendicular if x\cdot y = 0.

subsection.p: x\perp yx is orthogonal to y Notation: x\perp y means x\cdot y = 0.

bluebox.p: Since 0 \cdot x = 0 for any vector x, the zero vector is orthogonal to every vector in \R^n.

statement.p: Find all vectors orthogonal to v = \vec{1 1 -1}.

solution.p: We have to find all vectors x such that x\cdot v = 0. This means solving the equation 0 = x\cdot v = \vec{x_1 x_2 x_3}\cdot\vec{1 1 -1} = x_1 + x_2 - x_3. The parametric form for the solution set is x_1 = -x_2 + x_3, so the parametric vector form of the general solution is x = \vec{x_1 x_2 x_3} = x_2\vec{-1 1 0} + x_3\vec{1 0 1}. Therefore, the answer is the plane \Span\left\{\vec{-1 1 0},\;\vec{1 0 1}\right\}. For instance, \vec{-1 1 0}\perp\vec{1 1 -1} \sptxt{because} \vec{-1 1 0}\cdot\vec{1 1 -1} = 0.
